Science
Electron capture J. L. CHARLES
Synthetic blood research progressing
Researchers aim for stable perfluorocarbon emulsions that can carry high levels of oxygen and are eliminated rapidly from body tissues
Ron Dagani C&EN, Washington
Melvin looks like an ordinary white laboratory rat, except for some dis- turbing differences: The normally red beady eyes are transparent and colorless, and the ears and nose- once pink-have been bleached to a ghostly pallor.
Melvin's cosmetic problems can be attributed to his participation in an important medical experiment. The rodent's blood was drained and replaced with a synthetic substitute: a clear, colorless perfluorocarbon emulsion. Despite his whitewashed appearance, Melvin (not his real name) remains alive and well. He
and his bloodless kin at several lab- oratories are helping researchers to develop and evaluate the "second generation" of artificial blood sub- stitutes for human use.
The "first generation" of blood substitutes already has arrived and is about to enter medical practice. The Japanese government is on the verge of licensing the use of Fluosol- DA, a perfluorocarbon emulsion that has been tested on more than 500 patients, most of them in Japan. Approval could come as early as this summer. Moreover, clinical trials of Fluosol-DA are in progress through- out the U.S. The Food & Drug Ad- ministration could approve the emul- sion's use in this country as early as next year.
The excitement swirling around Fluosol-DA and other potential ar- tificial blood substitutes has been about 15 years in the making. In 1966, Leland C. Clark Jr. of Chil- dren's Hospital Research Foundation in Cincinnati showed that mice sub- merged in a beaker of a perfluoro- carbon could survive because they breathed the oxygen dissolved in the
liquid. Later, Robert P. Geyer of Harvard University replaced the en- tire blood supply of rats with per- fluorocarbons and watched them live- out a normal life span. In the 1970s, Ryoichi Naito, Kazumasa Yokoyama, and their colleagues at Green Cross Corp., Osaka, Japan, screened hun- dreds of perfluorocarbons in animals, searching for an effective and non- toxic replacement for blood. Their efforts eventually led to the devel- opment of Fluosol-DA.
In recent years, newer candidates for blood substitutes have begun to attract widespread attention. Chem- ists are playing a pivotal role in the development of these substances, as evidenced by some of the presenta- tions given at the recent national American Chemical Society meeting in Las Vegas.
Invariably, these new emulsions are measured against the existing standard, Fluosol-DA, an aqueous emulsion of perfluorodecalin (14 weight-to-volume %) and perfluoro- tripropylamine (6%) fortified with small amounts of inorganic salts and other ingredients. These additives
Many promising oxygen-carrying perfluorochemicals have cyclic structures

The "first generation" of blood substitutes already has arrived and is about to enter medical practice.
